div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: FRIENDSHIP WITH TURKEY.
div.p: Those British politicians who promised great things of the Pesce Congress at The Hague can scarcely have foreseen one of the advantages which this apparently futile meeting is said to have brought to their country. This advantage, a direct consequence of the Congress, is the greater friendship with Turkey. Those who think to understand the Balkan question by reading blue books will no doubt deplore any improvement of diplomatic relations, and the improvement of British commerce with Turkey is scarcely likely to sugar their pill. But it is worth while noting that several French authorities on the Macedonian question have stated that the English enthusiasts could never have their relorms carried out unless the British Ambasador were able to go before the Sultan Armed with a strong friendship and un challenged prestige Unfortunately it cannot be said that British prestige at Constantinople I ha been unchallenged of late.

An indefatigable and subtle diplomatist, Baron Marshall von Bieberstein has contrived that Germany should receive many sugar plums in the way of orders for guns, railway concessions, and what not, and British traders have itcbed at setog their profits stationary or declining. However, if we are to believe a writer in the Siècle,"fit is Great Britain now that leads the dance. Before leaving Constantinople for The Hague, Baron Marshall von Bieberstein omitted to see to it that a great bort to Turkish pride-her inclusion among the secondary Powers convoked to the congress-was removed. This, coming after a deception by Germany-withdrawing her sopport in the Tabah affair when things became serions-sufficed to change the Sultan's attitnde. Admiral Sir Charles Drury and the officers of the Mediterranean Fleet were recently received by the Sultan in a way which clearly signalised the bange. All precedents in the matter of etiquette were set aside, and the party were received with the opretnonial beretofore reserved to Princes of the Blood; And, in spite of the activity of the German Charge d'Affaires, a much better time for British merebants and financiers is promised.

div.head: THE SUEZ ROUTE.
div.p: "At a time when public attention in the United States has been recalled to the transfer of the Atlantic Pleet to the Pacific by Mr. Hearst once more raising the cry of the danger from Japan,' a very interesting suggestion bas been made by an American admiral, whose words will carry weight," says the "Evening Standard." "Rear-Admiral Clark is the cap tain of the famous battleship Oregon,' which steamed from the Pacific coast to Cuba, via the Straits of Magellan, at the outset of the war with Spain. He is strongly in favour of sending the Atlantic Pleet to the Pacific by way of the Suez Canal, owing to the dangers attending the passage of the Magellan Straits, the lack of good anchorage, and the tortuous run of 200 miles between Sandy Point and Port Pamine, 'where Vessels might encounter serious danger when proceeding in squadron formation. The admiral's objections are backed ap by statisticians, who prove that if the fleet proceeds via Sue to the Philippines it will bave 4364 fewer miles to cover, will conse quently take forty days over the voyage, as against fifty-six, and will save £80,000 over ita coal."

div.head: Lord Cromer as Politioian.
div.p: "The political incident of the revers may be provided by the active entry of Lord Cromer into public life at home," says the "Yorkshire Pont." "I have the best authority for saying that he contemplates taking a considerable part in the warfare between parties, not merely in Parliament, but also on the platform. And, furthermore, I am able to say that so far as the fiscal question is concerned he will be found an ontspoken free trader. Many Unionists are hoping that Lord Curzon may be induced by Lord Cromer's action to resome his position in public life."

div.head: Jowbalting by Natives
div.p: An antisemitic incident has recently engag. ed the attention of the Cairo summary native court. The defendants were a band of natives, who were charged with having attacked and maltrented a number of Jews attending a burial. The Court sentenced 8 of the accused to one month's imprisonment a piece, and another to 15 days' imprisonment. One of the alvocates for the defence pleaded that the "Lewa" declared the affair exaggerated and therefore asked for the acquittal of the accuser. A French contemporary comments as follows on the incident: ''Si dans la classe élevée et instruite, la parole du "Lewa" fait foi, aons nous demandons ce que la populace ne ferait pas quand on l'excite journellement, contre tout ce qui n'appartient pas à l'Islam."

div.head: Anolent Egypt.
div.p: Mr. Gerald Massey, a poet of much honour among the ardent youth of the Victorian era, has been silent so long that the announcement of a new book from his pen sounds strangely. It has engaged him for more than twenty years. "Ancient Egypt, the Light of the World," is its title, and in its two large volumes Mr. Massey develops the thesis that much Jewish and Christian doctrine has its source in Egypt, that, in fact, ortbodox Christianity largely arose from a literal misinterpretation of Egyptian myth and theosophy. Mr. Massey sees in Fgypt the birthplace of language and civiline tion, and his book has many chapters on my thology, on the primitive sign language and on Egyptian parallels to, or anticipations of Christian doctrines and legends Mr Fisher I'n win is the publisher

div.head:
THE CHOLERA.
PROTECTION OF EGYPT.
div.p: ELABORATE PRECAUTIONS.

The Egyptian authorities have decided to take a number of further precautions to protect this country from cholera, in addition to those enumerated in our issue of yesterday. A pil rim arriving at Alexandria, as well as at Port Said, from Russia, the Ottoman dominions, and the Balkans will be sent through in quaran. tine. On their arrival at Suez they will be placed under the supervision of the Egyptian Government and afterwards will be despatched to the Hecljaz. These precautions will contimue until next Monday, after which date the following more elaborate measures will be resorted to All steamers arriving from the above mentioned countries, which have pilgrims among their passengers, will he medically inspected and the pilgrims found on board will be taken in small batches to Suer with all the necessary quarantine pre cautions. Few pilgrims, however, are expected to arrive in this way, as already the steamer companies bere have sent telegraphic instrue tions to their agents in the countries affected not to receive pilgrims at all. But, in order not to put any unnecessary difficulties in the way of shipping, the quarantine authorities have decided that steamers, arriving with any pilgrims among the passengers are to be medically inspected and sent on in quarantine. The names and destinations of their fellow passengers will be taken and handed over to the sanitary authorities at Alexandria, Port Said and in the interior, who will keep them ander medical supervision for some days.

The great batches of Russian Moslem pil grims are passing through the Suez Canal to the Hedjaz in quarantine. As there is a danger of some of these being infected the Hedjaz will be carefully watched in order to prevent any chance of infection coming to Egypt.

These measures will entail an enormous amount of labour on the sanitary authorities, and expense to the country, but their imposition is considered to be fully jastifier in view of the urgency of the situation.
Dr. Roffer, President of the Quarantine Board, and Mr. Grahn, Director General of the Department of Public Health, are both arriving from Europe on Monday next.

div.head: UNITED AFRICAN EXPLORATIONS
div.p: The report of the United African Explora tions, Ltd., for the year ended 30th June last, to be submitted at the meeting on the 3rd states that there is a profit for the year of £39,818, which with the balance brought forward, makes A total of £46,006. The interim dividend of 10 per cent, paid in December last, absorbed, with income tax £10,000. There remains a halance of £36,006, out of which the directors recommend a final dividend of 5 per cent. and a bonus of 5 per cent., taking 20 per cent. for the year The directors propose to transfer £20,000 to the reserve fund, bringing it up to £45,000), and to carry forward £6,006 Mr. E T. Patterson has resigned his sent on Board, but the directors have elected Mr. W.R. Patterson in his place, and the shareholders nre askerl to confirm his election.

div.head: CAIRO TO CONSTANTINOPLE TELEGRAPH.
div.p: The telegraph line between Cairo and Constantinople is now in operation and mes sages can be sent from Cairo to London, via Constantinople and Budapest. The section from Constantinople to Beiront is worked with the Hagbes apparatus, but duplex machines Are employed between Beirout and Cairo. The cost of the line was £16,000, and it has taken eight months to construct. Messages are sent from Cairo to Constantinople at a rate of 1f. 10c per word.

The telegraph line between Cairo and Constantinople is now in operation and mes sages can be sent from Cairo to London, via Constantinople and Budapest. The section from Constantinople to Beiront is worked with the Hagbes apparatus, but duplex machines Are employed between Beirout and Cairo. The cost of the line was £16,000, and it has taken eight months to construct. Messages are sent from Cairo to Constantinople at a rate of 1f. 10c per word.

div.head:
RENTS IN CAIRO.
CONTINUED INCREASE
div.p: There appears to be no prospect of the enor mous house renta at present obtaining in Cairo falling during the present year. Indeed there is every indication of prices increasing rather than diminishing, despite the desperate state of financial depression through which we have been passing. In almost any street through which one passer, the hand of the builder is in evidence, new buildings are springing up on hitherto barren land, or rising to replace their more old fashioned predecessors which have fallen to meet the demand for more sanitary and commodious residences

The demolition of so many of these older buildings has naturally thrust a large number of house hunters upon the town, but this is in no manner a sufficient senson for the extra ordinary way in which a house or flat in shapi ped up at almost fabulous rental the moment it falls vacant. The following use is a good example of the existing state of aftairs. The lease of a fat which had been let for a term of years at LB. 60 expired this summer. Upon the landlord expressing his intention of raising the rent to LE 80 upon yearly agreement, the tenant left, and the flat was advertised to let--for three days, when it was relet for a term of three years at a rental of LE 120 per annum

One beats much grumbling at what is termed "exorbitant" rentals, and while they are undoubtedly hard upon those people whose salaries are not large, it is nevertheless true that a house - like other things-is worth what it will bring, that if the rentals were in reality too high for the people to support, they would of necessity cease to exist, and in the meanwhile it is comforting to know, that even in these days of financial depression there is at least one portion of the community which is prospering.

div.head: A FRANCO EGYPTIAN RECLUSE
div.p: The Inte M. Andeoud who recently left a legacy, which came as a godsend, to the Louvre of some £320,000, was a man of great oulture and kind heart, but of misshapen body. AL passionate love in early life disappointed him, I and thenceforth be renounced woman and mankind. He lived embittered in almost complete solitude, and one by one dropped all his friends. His morbid sensitiveness was such that in the one house where he used to go he took offence because one evening the mistres appeared in ball dress, and to his distorted taney did so to mock him, and he never set foot in that place again. Hin one consolation was collecting. He bought rare bindings, and leaves a library worth opwards of £16,000. Among the pictures he bought are Fragonards, Wattents, and Bouchers, some of the finest extant. His end was a pathetic as his life. He was advised to move to a warm climate, and went to Cairo, making up his mind to die. He shut himself up there some years ago in one room, which he never left. Doctors told him that he was virtually committing suicide, and he died without having been out of his one room. He was the son of a wealthy banker, who was also an art amateur, and who gave a collection of Spanish curios to the Clony Musenm

div.head: THE ALHAMBRA
div.p: A full house greeted The World's Famous Royal Illusionats Company under the director ship of Cav. C. Watry at its opening performance last evening, and if its enthusiastic reception is any criterion, the company should have a successful ron. It is indeed refreshing to turn from Italian and French comedy, and the usual music hall performance, to an exhibi tion of real talent and skill, and last night's audience gave every evidence of its appreciation of this class of entertainment.

Both Madam Delia and Cay. Watry are clever illosionists, producing most extraordinary things, --- from docks from a tub of water, to a baby from a bunch of shovings. -- but although they succeeded in entirely mystify ing their audience, their scenery and arrangements are more elaborate than their completeness of detail is perfect. Cav. Watry too might enhance his performance by curtailing to some extent his lengthy explanatory patter.

Exceedingly start in Mr. Felix Wigo on all manner of wheels, but had be confined himself to this part of his exhibition, of which he is, no doubt, an expert, instead of muddling through a series of simple juggling tricks, his pertonnance would have been better appreciated.

A set of cinematograph pictures occupies attention while arrangements are made for the erection of the huge cage in which Captain Robert exhibits a troupe of performing Polar bears, and the docility with which these animals carry out their various maneuvres reflects creclit upon their trainer in his complete mastery over such formidable brutes.

Evidence of some disappointment was expressed by those under the misapprehension that this combination, travelling onder an undubtedly English rame, were English. Bat whatever the nationality of the performers, Italians was the only language spoken.
An innovation at this theatre we were relieved to notice is an arrangement for ventilation through the roof.

div.head:
So NUBIAN EXPLORATIONS
REMARKABLE FINDS
div.p: After an eight months' sojourn abroad, D. Randall Moolver, curator of the Egyptian department of the museum of the University of Pensylvania, bus returned to New York with a large assortinent of rare and valuable additions to the museum, which he obtained in original excavations in Egypt.

Professor MacIver said that he was highly gratified with the results of his investigations, which he believes will add much to the knowledge of ancient Egypt. He spent four months in Nubin, and unearthed treasures of great value.

"I regard my Nubian excavations mof immense importance to sciences the professor said"Tost what significance they will have, it I will be hard to say for several months, as we unearthed tables bearing a language different from the general run of Egyptian inscriptions Dr. Max Muller is hard at work translating these from photographs sent to him, and we here to debipher them in time.

"Nabin has been disturbed comparatively little by modern excavators. I worked between the first and second cataracts of the Nile, near the towns Amadaha and Anibeh. At Amadaha there is a fine temple, which is very much in ruins now. We also found what might be call ed a fort, built in the eighteenth dynasty, the time of Thothmes II., which was about 1450 B.C.

"One of the most interesting things, however, was the Anibeh excavation. We came upon nine brick pyramids there, dating back to the twentieth dynasty. They are the only brick pyramids known of by a 'stele.' It is covered with inseript but no seientific research concerning them had been made...
The most valuable article which I obtained for the museum is very large engraved stone, which is called technically 3 stele.' It is cover ed with inscriptions about an ancient Prince called Merry."
The professor mid that none of the data obtained had reference to biblical characters, but there was much which threw light upon the early Coptic Church.

div.head: MR CHURCHILL'S AFRICAN TOUR
div.p: - Parther details are to hand by yesterday's mail concerning Mr. Winston Churchill's tour. He will arrive at Malta today, and will leave on Oet. 6th, on board H.M.S. "Venus. He I will pay a short visit to Cyprus, probably from the sth to the 13th, and will then proceed to Mombas, where he will land about the 25th, After spending a fortnight in British East Africa, he will cross Lake Victoris from Kisumu to Entebbe, whence he will travel through Uganda to Lake Albert. His return journey will be down the Nile, via Khartoum and Cairo, and be expects to reach England about the middle of Janvary. Mr. Churchill will be secompanied by Mr. Edward Marsh, of the Colonial Office, and by Major Gordon Wilson

div.head:
EGYPTIAN MUMMIES
NO FABRICATION
div.p: The soorn of Dr. R. Porrer, a German Egypt ologist, is excited by the accounts which have appeared in various European newspapers of the fabrication of fake mummies which are sold to simple collectors as the genuine article thonsands of years old. He writes, to the Strasburg "Post" to say that there isn't a word of truth in the story and that the periodical revival of stories of mummy factories in Paris and elsewhere must be placed in the same category with the sen serpent yarns.
"A false mommy manufacturer would die of starvation," says Dr. Porrer. "In the first place, there is no great demand for mummies

"Besides, the supply of mummies is practically Anexhaustible and the price of all ordinary one is so low that a manufacturer in Paris could not box his mummy and send it to Cairo to be sold for the price that the gengine article can be bought at there, with its painted casg and the certificate of the Cairo museum as to its genuineness.

"When I was in Egypt some years ago | SAW an illustration of the unlimited supply of mummies. Around El Akmin the fellahs hart dag sp hundreds of mummies to plander the coffins of the trinkets and other valuable objects often buried in them. The bodies and coffins were left tambled abont there in the most disgraceful way. They were commercially valueless, and the natives would not take the trouble to reinter them."
"To talk of a trade in false mommies is simply preposterous."

div.head: BRITISH TRADE WITH CYPRUS.
div.p: Very satisfactory evidence of the growth of British trade with Cyprus last year, compared with 1906, is given in a Colonial Office report jost published. To the total importa of £500,000, the United Kingdom contributed £158,000, or over 30 percent, this amount representing an increase of £8,000 on the previous ymr. Exports to this country robe by 241,000, or an increase of over 18 per cent, to £129,000. The tota exports from Cyprus to all countries amounted to £160,000, of which the British share represented 28 percent. In regard to importa, the United Kingdom hela the first place, Turkey being second with £105,000 bat Egypt came first megards exports with a total of £171,000, while the United Kingdom was soood. The improve ments in trade as regards this country were chiefly in provisions, coul, iron and steel mann factures and machinery, & certain talling off having taken place in hardware and cutlery and textiles. The total British trade for the ten years preceding 1906 smounted to £997,000, OR 97.9 percent., out of Agregato of £8,600,000 for all countriel ?

div.head: WEATHER REPORT
div.p: We have received the following report on the weather during September During September the weather in Egypt was normal in character. The only disturbance occurred on the 25th., when southerly winds were recorded as far oath m arion, using hot and oppressive weather. In the afternoon of the 25th the wind changed suddenly from southerly to northerly and the temperature fell rapidly in the way characteristic of the chose of khamsin, but this sodden change was not nocompanied by the usual rapid variation of the pressure. Pressure was above normal over the matern Mediterranean and over Reypt and in the Badan the departure was every where slight. Temperature was with few excep tions below normal. The rainfall of the month was in considerable defect on the Badan plains and at Roseires was about normal. The river levels have all passed their maxima. The read ing of Roseires page is a metre below the mean of the past seven years. At A gan the Nile rolle somewhat from the 16th to the oth in consequence of a waye in the Sobat, but the the gauge-rending is now 150 ems. below the Average of 35 year At El Obeid the minfall W unusually heavy. Northy of Khartoum heavy storms have occurred, causing w heat on the railway

The Sirdar, Sir Reginald Wingate, accompa nied by Lady Wingate and Dr. and Mr Aeland paid visit to Lord Blythat Blythewoord, Stan sted, on Toanday week, for the purpose of inspecting the farme in the moonpation of the Government for the researches of the Royal Commission on Tuberoulonis. Many congratulations were extended to Borton Bey yesterday on his appointment, by otheials of the siministration and others, and on behalf of our readers we extend to the new Postromster General our heartiest wishes fors brilliant carter in his new office, with full confidenon that extended progress will be made under his administration

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le ler Octobre 1907 à 5h. p.m. sous la présidence de Son Excellence le Dr. Sphiess Pacha.
Btaient présents : M.M. Becoffier, Ehrlich, RAIR, Mansour Bey Youssef et Tambaoopoulo, mein bres" . Sedky Bey, secrétaire général.
LA Délégation ajourne pour renseignements complémentaire l'examen d'une proposition dar service Vétérinaire pour l'acquisition d'un appareil "Richardson" destiné à l'abattage
chiens errants non réclamés.

Cominonication est donnée d'une telle que Mr. le Commandant de la Police informant que Mr. Kempner accepte les conditions qui lui ont été imposées pour l'exploitation de e voitures automobiles et transmettant le tarif qu'il se propose d'établir pour les dites voitures.

La Délégation, tout en faisant remarquer que ce tarif loi sen ble élevé, n'a pas spendant d'objection à son adoption à titre essentielle ment provisoire, sous réserves de modifications ultérieures et de tous droits de règlemeptation de la Municipalité sur la matière.
La Délégation renvoie aux services pour rapport les offres présentées :
1° pour les travaux d'empierrement et de analisation des mes Zeinel Abidin, Pharaon et Rollo.
2 pour la capalisation des rues El Einani el et El meu Aly.
pour la location du café et de restaurant da cola Nouzha
pour la foumiture pt le montage d'une vojo Decoyille devant servir au trisport des pierres provenant de la prière d'Abou Zabel..

La Delegation, apres examen des offres présenter sonstate que celle de MM. Baume et Marpent pour les travaux de construction de deux ponts sur le Canal Mahmoodlieh, est in plus basse et charge l'Ingénieur en Chef de la Wrification de calculs joints leur soumission AN

Avant de prendre uno deision an sujet des reques présghties par la société Anonyme le Khedive insi que MM. Dégiardé pour la confection de routes situées entre le roes Salah el Din et Abou al Dunder, la Délégation est d'avis de demander aux intereses pour quelle somme ils seraient disposés de contribuer à la dépense.
Ser rapport de Mr. Poster qui avait été charge de la désignation d'un side d'ingénieur che pour les travaux d'astainissement, la De légation nomme à ce poste Mt Silver Dawson

La Délégation serait disposée de faire droit à une demande de la Société des Presses Libres Beyptiennes et de la Deutsche Baumwollpresse pour Te dallage d'ane ruelle située entre la rue da ler Khediye et'la rue Binani, la condition que les tres contribuent pour moitié à la dépense qu'il consentent à payer les frais de rehaussement de certains travaux de pavage des ruelles avoisinantes que le travail demande entrainernit

L'Ingénieur en Chef ayant communiqué le deyis des travaux d'entretien et de réparation dengusis effectuer otte année entre le Gouvernorat et la cale neshe do Kait Bey, devis se montant a LE. 700 environ, la Délégation, va l'agence qu'il y a à effectuer oes travaux, décide de le mettre immédiatement en extention, sous reserye de la régularisation ultérieure per la Commission Monicipale
Le Conseil de Tanzim aura lieu Jeudi A 5h. př. sous la présidence de S.E. Schriess Pacha
La séance est levée à 7 h. p.m.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Angourd'hui à midi)

Londres sert toujours de pompe aspirante nos valeurs dirigeantes qui naturellement en rofitent, tout en restant néanmoins au-des ous des prix cotto au Stock Exchange. Ici, ien que le mouvement sit été moins précis u'hier et ne soit moins limité aux gros titres, 302-ci n'en ont pas moins continué à fournir principal contingent des transactions, qui, Ito anos de le dire, ont été clairsemées et oins importantes encore que les jours passés. est vers la fin de la séance qu'on a remarqué urtout de la faiblesse, le début ayant été nes ferme et plutôt hasier. Avec un horizon insi réduit, on conçoit facilement qu'à part sans acheteurs, de même que l'Urbaine 8 18/16 Les Lunghis étaient demandées à 9/32. La Levico, assez traitée hier, était plutôt négligée anjourd'hui.

A signaler une nouvelle vente aux enchères de 38 obligations nonvelles Crédit Poncier Egyptien. Celles-ci ont trouvé preneur au cours du jour, soit 254 francs. Ces obligations faisai ent partie du paquet que la Cassa di Sconto est en train de liquider graduellement.

A part les quelques fluctuations, d'ailleurs insignifiantes, que nous avons ci-dessus énu mérées, il n'y a pas en d'autres variations. La tendance générale est difficile préciser, Comme nous l'avons dit hier, ou constate que notre marché soit péniblement l'exemple donné par le Stock Exchange. Il va sans dire pourtant que si la demande persiste à Londres, l'égalité de niveau se rétablira par la force même des chores et pourra entrainer de ce fait une reprise correspondante sur nos bonnes valeurs exclusivement locales, condition que les banques viennenten aide à la spéculation. Tant mieux dans ce cas, pourvu que la hausse soit raisonnée et qu'on ne retombe pas dans les errements passés.

div.head: Circulaire A. De Vries et Boutigay
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Mereredi 2 Detobre. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné invarié à 8 7/8 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consplidé anglais a gagné hier 3/8 à 82 3/8. L'Unifiée est restée inchangée à 102. La National Bank a haussé de 12 à 22 3/8, et ls Daira de 3/8 . 14. L'Agricole été soutenue à 8 1/2 et la Delta Light 10 1/4
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a perda 2 franca d 702, et la Banque d'Athènes 6 francs à 118. Les Lots Turos se sont raffermis à 171.

loi, le marché qui montrait ces quelques derniers jours un peu de mauvaise humeur deyant les basses successives de nos valeurs en Europe, s'est décidé aujourd'hui à suivre le mouvement et il ne l'a pas fait à moitia.

Des l'ouverture, les transactions ont été très suivies et une grande animation a régnai jos qu'à la cloure faisant bansser un pou toutes les valeurs, qui s'étaient déjà signalées à l'at tention par leur reprise du mois d'Août. Certains titres ont fait même un véritable bond, encourages d'ailleurs par l'allure baussière de la National Bank, de l'Agricole et autres gros ses valeurs

la séance d'aujourd'hui est-elle le signal de la reprise durable que l'on prédit depuis si longtemps ! - c'est probable, et s'il devait survenir une réaction, elle ne Rurait nuire à la hausse définitive qui se produits forcé ment parce que logique et reposant sur des bases sérieuses,

Doos le compartiment des Banques, la NA tional Bank fait un bond de 1/2 livre à 22 1/4 5/16. L'Agricole hausse à 8 7/16. La Banque d'Orient se tasse 120 tandis que la Casse di Soonto remonte à 44-45. Le Comptoir Pinan cier se relève à 2 7/8-15/16.

La Delta Laghtavance : 101/4. Les Jonissances Baux du Caire gagnent 4 franes 194. LA Dairn Sanieh progresse de 3/8 à 13 13/16. LA part de fondateur Credit Poncier Bgyptien re cule à 710 et l'obligation ancienne est demandée à 299-300, LA Bébéra se consolide à 20 1/8 ainsi que l'Allotment à 2 3/8 L'Enterprise and Development réagit à 9 et sa partà 13.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nongovich haussent en quelques minutes à 16 et les Brehler sont recherchés à 6. Les Ritz anivent 1011/16 en gain de 1/16.

Parmi les petites valeur, la Delta Land se raffermità 1 3/4 de même que les Fatates 0 11/16. Les Markets rétrogradent à 27/9. L'A boukir est en progres à 28'6 et les Ordinary Khedivial Mail également à 21/3.

Nous informons nos lecteurs que la H. de Vries and Boutigny Limited a transféré définitivement ses bureaux "me Soliman Pacha No. 10" Immeuble Osman Bey Chérif, à coté de l'immeuble de la Standard Life.

Nous recevons un télégramme de Marseille nous annonçant que M. Henri de Vries, admi nistrateur délégué de notre société s'embarine aujourd'hui sur le paquebot allemand, desti nation d'Alexandrie, o il sera rendu le lundi 8 courant

div.head:
FRANCE AND MOROCCO.
A SULTAN'S SUPPORT.

div.p: Mohamed Yazi declared in an interview that Sultan Abd el Axis has decided to support France in the re-establishment of order and the organisation of a police force. General Liautey will accompany Mr. Regnault and General Philipert to Rabat next week. (Hanas)

The Bulgarian Exarchate is supporting the Porte in suppressing meinlism. A circular has been sent to the bishops priests, and school master forbidding them to assist Macedonian bands. 40 teachers suspected of agitation have heen dismissed. (Reus)

div.head:
AMERICA YACHT CUP.
BIR T. LIPTON'S DECISION

div.p: Sir Thomas Lipton has telegraphed to the Royal Irish Yacht Club regretting that the moe for the America Cup must be abandoned w it is impossible to build yacht to cross the Atlantie and compete on equal terms with a yacht not crossing the Ocean, (Reuter)

The Press is satisfied with the Austro-Russian note and thinks that the fact that it is addressed to all the Balkan capitals is a hope. fulaugury. The representatives of the Powers at Sofia, Athens, and Belgrade have been directed to support the Austro-Russian repreentations Reiter
The Emperor and Empress will visit Queen Wilhelmina at the close of their visit to England (Reuter)
The Kaiser will leave shortly on a visit to Queen Wilhelmina. Hanse)
The British troops have evacuated the hin. terland (Reuter)

The funeral of the Grand Duke of Baden will take place at Carlsruhe on Monday. It is expected that the Emperor and all the German sovereigns will attend. The Duke of Connaught will represent the King. (Reuter)

The "Times" learns from Tokio that the Korean insurrection is virtoally quelled. The insurgents have lost 800 killed and several thousands wounded: Two Japanese regiments engaged had 15 killed and 40 wounded (Reuter)
The ballot of the boiler-makers has resulted in the majority supporting the agreement between their executive and employers regard ing sectional strikes. This will probably avert a lockout. (Render)
The Emperor is suffering from hoarseness. All audiences have been suspended. His Mojesty is going to Schoenbrunn for rest but will attend to current business. (Reuter)
The Emperor who is suffering from a cold in consequence of the fatigue entailed by the recent receptions, has gone to Schoenbrum. (Hange)
Mr. Pallières has arrived at Loupillon (Harva)

The Money Market.

There has been a decidedly firmer tone prevalent in the money market this week, and rates show substantial appreciation. Yesterday 37 per cent. was the general quota tion for short loans, and in few case, as muok as 41 per cent was demanded. As there is no immediate pressure for money, it is assumed that the present hardening tendency is due to the fact that Lombard Street is husbending its resources in anticipation of the autumn demands for Egypt and other quarters.
- This week another £280,000 in sovereigns has been withdrawn for Egypt, making a total of £480,000 to date.

The Bank retum is not quite so satisfactory. A small sum was returned from the provinces, but against this has to be set the withdrawal of £426,000 for export, so that the stock of coin and bullion is lower by £866, ono. The note cuculation also increased by £361,000, so that the reserve shows a shrinkage of £717,000 to £98,089,000. This, however, compares very favourably with last year, when the total at this period was only £23,881,416.
The proportion of reserve to liabilities is slightly lower on the week, being now 61-80 per cent. as against 51.67 per cent.

There has been a renewal of the Continental demand for bar gold, but the price was about a below last week's high level, at 77/10d. The Bank of England secured £200,000 of the £600,000 arriving. In addition to the £280,000 withdrawn for Egypt, £100,000 has left the Bank for Constantinople, and smaller sums, amounting in all to £116,000, have been taken for Ronmania, Italy, and Gibraltar

div.head: Silver,
div.p: market, and the tone has been very firm. The quotation for bar silver has advanced to 31 } for immediate and 31,5/16 for forward delivery

div.head: The Stook Markota.
div.p: Whatever may be said regarding their business methods, members of the Stock Exchange are nothing if not up-to-date in the matter of their amusements. The latest importation from France, the "Diabolo" game, has already found its way into the "House," and in the early part of this week the time not taken up with the arrangement of the settlement has been largely docupied in acquiring proficiency in the new game.
Only a small open account was revealed by the settlement, hence there was little difficulty in completing this.

During the past two or three days the tone has been much more satisfactory. The business done has not been on a large sole, it is true, but there has been an appreciable increase in investment orders, which is a very welcome sign. The confidence of brokers has been much strengthened by the publication of the terms of the new Anglo-Russian convention, which has been a strong ball point for international securities. It is rightly recognised that the new arrangement with Great Britain will do much to restore Rassian prestige in Europe, and from the financial standpoint this can bring nothing but good results. Another satisfactory point is the improved out look regarding the railway crisis. It is now believed that a strike is but a remote possibility, and one newspaper announce with the show of authority, that it has good reason to believe the dispute will be settler without recourse to a strike. The joumal add that a section of the directors are inclined to recognise the Amalgamated Society on the lines conceded by the Postmaster General to the Associations of Post Office servants last year. Of course nothing definite can be known until a reply bas been received from the Railway Companies Association to the invita tion to meet the men's representatives in conference, but it is hoped that the decision will be such as will lead to an amicable settle ment of the pointe in question.
To-day the market has been quiet, and the tone is good.

div.head: Console.
div.p: The market for gilt-edged stocks has been generally steadier this week, although Consols have at !imes shown a slight tendeney to sag. Yesterday the premier security left off with a gain of 1/16 at 823 for the account, and there has been an improvement of 1/16 in the cash quotation to-day, at 82

div.head: Foreign Bonde
div.p: The international market has been active, thanks to the cheerful feeling imparted by the publication in detail of the provisions of the new convention between Great Britain and Russia. Although at the outset Rossians and Japanese showed a slight set-back after the advance last week, they have for the greater part of the week been in strong request. Yesterday Russian Fours further advanced to 777, and the Fives to 873 Japanese were also to t higher, the first series of Fives being quoted 1004, and the first 4 per cents. 92).
To-day foreign bonds have not moved much Japanese 44 % are lower, but Rossians are "unaltered.

div.head: Homo Ralle
div.p: On the whole the tone of the home railway market has been much firmer this week. The conciliatory tone adopted by Mr. Bell in his speech at Cardiff on Sunday produced an op timistic feeling on Monday, and shares were quite buoyant, repurchases by bears anxious to cover sales before the carry-overcruising prices to rise rapidly. There was some falling away later in the day, but at the close several advances of 1 to 1were marked.
The market has continued steady. Several of the stocks of the heavies were subjected to a bear attack yesterday, but the losses were only small on balance.
Home mils have been good in tone today. Great Western and South Bestern "A" have advanced ), and Great Northern Deferred.

div.head: Americans
div.p: There has been little of interest in the American seotion since our last, and investors have shown no inolination to afford support. The more reasonable attitude of the United States Government towards the trusts, noticeable in the announcement that they had decided to withdraw the action against the Chicago and Alton Railway in respect of the alleged grant ing of rebates, caused a favourable impression, but business was too sparse to permit of any real advantage aceruing as the result of the announcement
To-day Americans have declined. Upions and Milwaukee have lost 2, at 1327, and 122 respectively

div.head: Egyptiane.
div.p: This week Egyptian shares have again been an active feature, and prices all round have established a further advance. The favourable report on the financial position in Egypt made by a solicitor who has been out there in the interests of the banks involved in the recent crisis has been received with much satisfáotion, and in the best circles it is now hoped that the coming season may see a return of confidence and active dealings in Egyptian stocks and shares.

National Bank have again risen, and the price last night was up to 21, closing tonight at 21H. Agricultural Bank are practically unchanged at 8 5/16-4. The Preference of the latter are again in demand at 9 3/16), the 3 per cena Debentures remaining steady at 84-86. Egyptian Estates have been largely dealt in at 11/16, and they keep very steady at this price.

div.head: Mining
div.p: South African mining shares have been quiet. The statement made by the chairman at the meeting of the Vaal River Co. in Kimberley that he was convinced that ultimately their operations would, under careful management, be attended with great success, caused a spurt in these shares on Wednesday, the price at one time going to 1,11/16. Tanganyika also improved after the recent liquidation,
Yesterday New Vaal River relapsed 5/16 to 17, and Tanganyika were 3'32 down at 34 Kaffirs have been firm, but quotations show little change. Mining shares have been doll to day
There is nothing new to report regarding Egyptian mining shares, which are neglected.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The troopship "Sicilia, which has just left Southampton with troops on board for the Mediterranean garrisons will arrive at Alex andris on the Tth October, and will land a big lot of drafts for the Inniskilling Dragoona, Royal Horse Artillery Royal Garrison Artill ery, King's Own Scottish Borderers, Royal Inniskilling Pasiliers, Royal Dublin Pasiliers, and other corps in Egypt. The "Sicilia" will leave on the 8th for Southampton, calling at Malta and Gibraltar en voyage.

The death has just taken place of Colonel B.D.A. Donne, formerly of the Royal Sussex Regiment, and the Egyptian Army. He was closely identified with the Khedive's army trom 1888 to 1898, and raised and commanded that very smart corps, the 10th Sudanese Battalion. How a lot of service in Reypt including the Egyptian War, 1882, Nile Bxp edition, 1884-85, and the Soudan Expeditions of 1888-89, and the actions of Gemsisah, Toski, eto, Old friends of his in Egypt will learn of his death with great regret us he was a very popular officer, and a good soldier,

The battleship "Renown"-long known in the Royal Navy by the nickname of "Jackey's Pet" from Sir John Fisher's inordinate fondDess of her ms flagship in many waters being refitted, and it is believed that she is der tined for another pleasure cruise. Since the "Renown" was fitted out to convey the Prince of Wales to India she has been without most of her armament, and has retained many of the characteristics of a Royal yacht. The fact that her guns are not being restored to her has given rise to the rumour that she will be used to carry the Duke of Connaught to Malta in December, when he takes up the new post of Commander of the Mediterranean Garrison early in the year. The "Renown". has been on the active list of the Naty since 1898, and has Always borne the reputation of being remark ably comfortable ship even in a beavy sa way. She bow anks as a battleship of second class only. The "Renown" carried the flag of Admiral Fisher on the Mediterranean station, 18991900

The two Dreadnoughts which will be laid down at Portsmouth and Devonport respeetively next month, will be improvements on the existing battleships of that type. Their displace ments will be increased to 19,800 tons each as compared with the 18,300 tons of the Belle rophon and her consorts, and the big gun armament will be more powerful, and the se condary batteries will be mounted with heavier guns. These improvements are the natural out come of experience in building these monsters Some years ago, the trend of Daval opinion was largely in favour of small battleships, with powerful guns, and complete protectionon the prisciple that it is dangerous to place all one's eggs in one basket-but latterly Bri tain led the way in big ships and other nations must needs follow. Indications are not want ing that other nations, with the exception, perhaps of Germany, are getting tired following out this bopless contest the two new Dreadnoughts are to be finisbed inside two years.

One consequence of the motor bas having come to stay is giving the Army Council some concern. In the South African War, the London bus home covered himself with honour in competing against horsee brought from all points of the compass. Whether tagging guns, drawing stores, or even as a genuine cavalry. man's mount, he showed a stamina and speed that were simply surprising. Bat the advent of the petrol driven motor bus threatens his very existence, and the War Office in naturally alarmed at the possible disappearance of a valuable and reliable source of supply in war time. Many of the big companies and bus proprietons enjoy small annual subsidy in return for the right of purchase in time seed, and it is understood that this subsidy will now be increased and extended to other horse owners. The borsed bas is dying hard, and even yet it is doubtful if the mechanically driven bus can compete financially with the older vehicle as y dividend coming concern.
